I appreciate your elaboration on the importance of the role economists play in decision-making processes and the value they add in reducing uncertainty. Indeed, their expertise in theories, principles, and data and the insights they provide into policy formulation and economic forecasting are significant.

However, the keyword here is 'overrated.' When we discuss being overrated, it includes not just the value and importance of the role but also the perception of the role and the expectation from it. Economists indeed contribute to significant decisions, but it becomes problematic if society begins to perceive them as infallible predictors of complex economic outcomes. Placing an unreasonable expectation or faith in their predictions, which are bound by the assumptions and models they use, can lead to disappointment when the real-world outcome deviates from their forecasts.

Thereby, while I fully endorse the vital role that economists have in our society, I also firmly believe that we should cautiously regard their models and forecasts as guides rather than certainties. This approach helps ensure we don't overrate their abilities through unrealistically high expectations, considering the inherent uncertainties in economic behavior. Thus, I maintain a balanced position on this discussion.
